body:
qTox now prints a lot of these:

```
[16:15:53.590 UTC] core/toxlogger.cpp:57 : Warning: "ERROR:network.c:sendpacket:509: attempted to send message with network family 10 (probably IPv6) on IPv4 socket"
```

comment_data.body: Can you test this at the same versions as I listed in #1027?
I am having this too. A ton of these messages, multiple every second. Toktok v0.2.5... it was not the case before; not sure if the logs were not there or if the issue wasn't.
@LittleVulpix can you test with the 3 specific versions I listed it #1027?
@iphydf I may be misunderstanding but I thought all of the ones from #1027 are already in toktok 0.2.5. If that is not the case I can try to compile tox myself and test it.
Yes that's the case. I'm trying to find out when it started.
@iphy i will test with the 3 versions tonight ...
@yurivict can you confirm that this does not happen in 0.2.3?
Do you guys set the logger level to anything specific when building toxcore or are you leaving it default?
Not sure if anything was done about this for 0.2.6; but as for @nurupo 's question, I think the logger is set to default in Miranda.
this happens since the logging for this was introduced. we need to investigate the root cause and disable this logmessage for now
Just a note that I still saw this on v0.2.9, and am still seeing this on v0.2.10 (both with qTox).
This is still going on with toxcore-0.2.10,1 on FreeBSD.

It looks like this error message means what it says: it's logged every 
time we try to send a packet to an IPv6 address if we only have an IPv4 
socket, which will be the case if the ipv6_enabled option was disabled.

Should we be printing an error in this case? Maybe a warning would be 
more appropriate? Or even nothing?

The error was added by @iphy in 21675ce0d. Maybe iphy could comment on 
the reasoning?
When you create a socket, you specify ```PF_INET``` or ```PF_INET6```. It can't be both. So you first create a socket with  ```PF_INET``` and the send IPv6 packets into it?

>So you first create a socket with  ```PF_INET``` and the send IPv6 
>packets into it?

We don't actually send any IPv6 packet on an IPv4 socket, because any  
attempt to do so is caught and this error is logged.

I reckon if the user has explicitly disabled IPv6, then he or she are expecting this behavior - in which case it shouldn't be seen or treated as an error. Can the error message be disabled in this case? I do not know how Tox's code is structured, but perhaps we should not even attempt to send an IPv6 packet whatsoever if the option is disabled?
@zugz @iphydf i think we should log these only with debug log level. what do you guys think?
Yes, DEBUG sounds good to me.

title: Beginning with 0.2.4, a lot of errors are printed: attempted to send message with network family 10 (probably IPv6) on IPv4 socket
